title: What are some of the best cover songs you have heard? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ah I think this just about covers it..... Note: originals in brackets [ ]; —- those I feel are as good or worthy as original have a [!] Also, this is the ‘best’ cover songs, not all of them. "[I Can't Get No) Satisfaction"  Devo [!] / Cat Power [The Rolling Stones] "[I Know) I'm Losing You"  Rod Stewart / Rare Earth [!] [The Temptations] "After Midnight"  Eric Clapton [JJ Cale] "All Along The Watchtower”  Jimi Hendrix [!] / Dave Mason / XTC / Lisa Gerrard [Bob Dylan] "All Mixed Up"  Red House Painters [The Cars] "Also Sprach Zarathustra"  Deodato [Richard Strauss] "American Woman"  Lenny Kravitz, 1998 / Butthole Surfers [Guess Who, 1970] "Apache Drop Out"  Edgar Broughton Band [a fusion of Captain Beefheart's 'Dropout Boogie' & The Shadows' "Apache"] "As Tears Go By"  Marianne Fathful [2 versions] [!] / Nancy Sinatra [The Rolling Stones] "Back Door Man"  The Doors [!] [Willie Dixon] "Bang a Gong"  Powerstation, 1985 / Blondie, 1993[T-Rex] "Bang Bang"  Nancy Sinatra [!] [Cher] "Beast of Burden"  Bette Midler [Rolling Stones] "Because The Night"  10,000 Maniacs w Natalie Merchant [Bruce Springsteen & Patti Smith] "Bouree"  Jethro Tull [J.S. "Dear Prudence"  Siouxsie & the Banshees [The Beatles] "Don't Dream It's Over"  Six Pence None the Richer [Crowded House] "Everybodys Talking"  Harry Nillson [Fred Neil] "Femme Fatale"  Big Star [Isaac Hayes, Sam & Dave] "I Want You"  Sophia Hawkins [Bob Dylan] "I'm a Man"  Chicago [Spencer Davis Group] "Iron Man"  the Cardigans [Black Sabbath] "It's All Over Now"  The Rolling Stones I added a [!] for those covers that -IMHO- equaled or surpassed the original. [edit #2] Corrections & updates for Twist & Shout, Watchtower, Bang A Gong & Wild Thing plus formatting changes

I am a HUGE fan of covers, and could write about this topic for days, but one thing I love is covers sung by the opposite gender. The obvious dichotomy is so freeing. The song can almost transcend the mortal coil of the singer, and just exist in the realm of words, and melody, and conviction. Here are some of my favorites: “R-E-S-P-E-C-T”Original artist: Otis ReddingCover artist: Aretha FranklinComment: It would be a little jarring even today for a woman to sing about the hardship of working all day and being the breadwinner, while just begging for a little lovin’ and respect from her spouse when she gets home at the end of the day; when Aretha covered this song in the 1960s, it was an unknown concept. Yet, she dominated the song with such ferocity and skill that nobody even seemed to notice, much less care.  “Valerie”Original artist: The ZutonsCover artist: Amy Winehouse This song is about a man who has stumbled across an old girlfriend that he is clearly still in love with. The woman seems to be…let’s say…problematic (putting it mildly), but even still, he invites her over, and seems to be trying to get back with her. Knowing the struggles Amy had in her own life, it’s not hard to imagine that she was drawn to the song more as wish fulfillment in behalf of the woman, and less from the perspective of the man. Anyway, she recorded a studio version of this song with Mark Ronson in 2007, but I’m partial to the messy and acoustic live version she did for AOL:  “Jolene”Original version: Dolly PartonCover artist: The White Stripes I love angst. I love Dolly. I love Dolly’s version of this song. But I also love punk covers and I adore The White Stipes. Put it all together, and you have the most absurd, but deeply satisfying, cover of “Jolene” (an oft covered song) imaginable. In this version, Jack decides to do away with any melodic middleman altogether, and just mainlines the pain—raw and vulnerable. His bleating voice at the end is devastating. And I love it.  Speaking of punk covers, my favorite punk cover band in the world is the only famous one: Me First and the Gimme Gimmes. I love their covers so much that it’s hard for me to pick one, but their 2014 album Are We Not Men? We Are Diva!, they only covered songs by female artists—including “Jolene.” However my favorite opposite gender song from them is: “Cabaret”Originally from the musical Cabaret, made famous by Liza Minelli in the 1972 film versionCover artist: Me First and the Gimme Gimmes There is nothing extraordinary about this cover, and probably says more about my musical tastes than anything. Still, I think the song typifies how reckless punk covers are, their inherent and paradoxical comedy and pathos, and why I love them so much.  “To Make You Feel My Love”Original artist: Bob Dylan (of course)Cover artist: Adele This song is pretty gender neutral, but it marked a turning point for me personally: it was the song that introduced me to Adele back in 2009. Good stuff.

Here are twenty! I hope you find something you like. 01 - Return of the Rat by the Wipers as covered by Nirvana.  02 - Come Together by the Beatles covered by Soundgarden.  03 - Ça plane pour moi by Plastic Bertrand. Cover by Sonic Youth.  04 - Marvin Gaye's Sexual Healing covered by Soul Asylum.  05 - Stevie Wonder's Higher Ground covered by the Red Hot Chili Peppers.  06 - Over the Top by Motörhead (Lemmy, Rock in Peace) covered by Mudhoney.  07 - Save a Prayer by Duran Duran covered by the Eagles of Death Metal.  08 - Wars Pigs by Black Sabbath covered by Faith No More  09 - Super Freak by Rick James as covered by Mordred  10 - Sin's a Good Man's Brother by Grand Funk Railroad as covered by Monster Magnet  11 - Dire Straits' Money for Nothing covered by Royal Trux  12 - Slade - Cum on Feel the Noize. Cover by Oasis.  13 - Seek & Destroy by Metallica. Cover by Steve'n'Seagulls.  14 - Friday I'm In Love by the Cure. Cover by Yo La Tengo.  15 - Soundgarden's Black Hole Sun covered by Agata Kubiak ( no youtube link only Spotify ) 16 - Christian Prommer's Drumlesson doing Daft Punk's Around the World  17 - Don't Leave Me this Way by Harold Melvin & the Bluenotes as covered by the Communards  18 - James Brown's Super Bad as covered by Lassigue Bendthaus better known as Atom™ / Señor Coconut  19 - Depeche Mode's Personal Jesus as covered by Johnny Cash  20 - Eight Miles High by the Byrds as covered by Hüsker Dü  I am working on the next 20 !

One of my most favorite cover songs in terms of overall music, concept, and execution is a cover version of the Beatles, "A Day in the Life" by a novelty group called Big Daddy.  Big Daddy was a group that recorded for the novelty/reissue label Rhino Records back in the 1980s.  The gimmick of the group was that they pretended to be an American rock 'n' roll group that got shot down over Vietnam while on a USO tour in the early 1960s.  Somehow, as the story goes, the band survived, but they did not return from captivity and get back to American until the 1980s.   Big Daddy would play 1980s hits in the style of 1950s and early 1960s rock band and even released a single of their cover version of "Eye of the Tiger."  Their best song, which they used to conclude their own song-by-song remake of the Beatles' Sgt. Pepper album, is a cover version of "A Day in the Life," but since the band plays the song "in character," they do it in the style of Buddy Holly.   The Beatles, "A Day in the Life" is stitched together from lyrics that John Lennon and Paul McCartney wrote separately, which means that the original song shifts styles several times.  Big Daddy handles the stylistic shifts in their own cover version of "A Day in the Life" by playing in the style of different Buddy Holly songs.  At first, Big Daddy's cover starts out in a style that's party "Peggy Sue," part "Oh Boy." Then when the song gets to the point when the vocals in the Beatles original shift to Paul McCartney ("Woke up fell out of bed..."), the style of the song suddenly shifts to mimic Buddy Holly's "Everyday."  Then, it quotes some Mexican-style guitar (which frequently showed up on Buddy Holly records).  Instead of using an orchestra for the drawn-out epic final chord of the song, Big Daddy substitutes the surprisingly similar sound of a plane crashing.  The song then ends with a recreation of a radio broadcast of a news story about the death of Richie Valens, Big Bopper, and Buddy Holly.  The cover version is conceptual brilliant it is exactly how a 1950s rocker like Buddy Holy might have chosen to cover the Beatles if he had been stuck in cryogenic suspension since 1959.

What are some of the best cover songs you have ever heard? Some of my favourite cover songs: Joss Stone’s and Rob Thomas’ cover of Stevie Nicks' and Tom Petty's “Stop Draggin’ My Heart Around”. Joss and Rob have amazing chemistry. Killer rendition of the song.  Jimmy Wayne’s cover of Hall and Oates' “Sara Smile". Hey, i'm Sara and I'll smile a while for Jimmy, lol.  Prince, Tom Petty, Steve Winwood, Jeff Lynne and others’ cover of George Harrison's "While My Guitar Gently Weeps". Prince’s guitar solo is out of this world.  Walk Off the Earth’s cover of Madonna’s “Material Girl”. Sarah Blackwood looks like the most energetic pregnant woman ever! Fun video.  Cher's cover of Marc Cohn's “Walking in Memphis”. Cher nailed it.  Linda Ronstadt's covers of the Rolling Stones’ “Tumbling Dice and Dee Dee Warwick's “You're No Good”. The power of Ronstadt's voice is unbelievable. This performance of “You're No Good" is one of the best I've ever heard.  Sinéad O'Connor’s cover of Prince’s “Nothing Compares 2U. It's such a hauntingly beautiful song.

Bridge Over Troubled Water -Aretha Franklin (originally recorded by Simon and Garfunkel)April Fools - Aretha Franklin (Dionne Warwick)I'm In Love With the German Film Star - the Foo Fighters (The Passions)Nothing Compares 2 U - Sinead O'Connor (Prince)Tennessee Flat-Top Box - Rosanne Cash (Johnny Cash)Viva Las Vegas - Shawn Colvin (Elvis Presley)I Think We're Alone Now - Lene Lovich (Tommy James and the Shondells)Venus - Bananarama (Shocking Blue)Take Me In Your Arms - Doobie Brothers (Kim Weston)Cry Baby - Janis Joplin (Garnet Mimms)Downtown - the B-52's (Petulia Clark)Hushabye -The Beach Boys (The Mystics)Black Magic Woman - Santana (Fleetwood Mac)The Night They Drove Old Dixie Down -Joan Baez (The Band)Passionate Kisses - Mary-Chapin Carpenter (Lucinda Williams)Honky Tonk Parts I & II - James Brown (Bill Doggett)Hands down I love Colvin's cover (#6) of Viva Las Vegas. Her version, paints a more darker image, that I believe, reflects the true meaning of the lyrics. As for #9, it's a toss up, depending on my mood. As for #12, I love the guitar in the Mystics version, but the Beach Boys vocals, win out. Different musical styles make it a tossup for #16, but I'll go with the Godfather of Soul's version, if only for the great opening dialogue he has with his backup band, the Famous Flames. Only Doggett's version made the top 40, going to #2, in 1956.

A Spotify playlist I put together to collect the responses in this and related threads.  Follow the playlist and I'll update as new responses are posted.  Covers: the Quora Collective Too many to be listed here but I will indulge myself a little: U2 performing Dylan's All Along the Watchtower for the Rattle & Hum movie.Faith No More (Lionel Richie's) EasyColdplay (Michael Jackson's) Billie JeanDaughtry (Lady Gaga's) PaparazziGarth Brooks (Kiss's) Hard Luck WomanIndigo Girls (Bob Dylan's) Tangled Up in BlueAtaris (Henley's) Boys of SummerSting (Hendrix's) Little WingSting (Beatle's) A Day in the LifeConcrete Blond (Hendrix's) Little WingSocial Distortion (Johnny Cash and June Carter Cash) Ring of FireBeth Hart (Led Zeppelin's) Whole Lotta Love (live at the Paradiso)Puddle of Mudd (Elton John's) Rocket ManElton John (Pete Townsend's) Pinball WizardBig Head Todd & the Monsters (Eric Clapton's) Forever Man (Live at the Fillmore)Goo Goo Dolls (Supertramp's) Give a Little Bit (Live in Buffalo)Halestorm (Daft Punk's) Get LuckyHalestorm (Lady Gaga's) Bad RomanceHalestorm (AC/DC's) Shoot to ThrillHalestorm (Benetar's) Hell is for ChildrenHalestorm (Jay Z / Alicia Keys) Empire State of MindHootie & the Blowfish (Radney Foster's) A Fine LineAgent Orange (Jefferson Airplane's) Somebody to Love The Conspirators, Bono, Sting, Joan Baez, Bryan Adams, Lou Reed, Jackson Browne for Amnesty International's Human Rights Concerts: 1986 Conspiracy of Hope (Bob Dylan's) I Shall Be Released

This is a wonderful question. I agree with several posters on many great covers. I originally read this question at work and kept including the words “epic” and “rock” in my mind as part of the original question which I see is not the case. However, replacing the word “best” with “epic” helps me keep the list pretty short, so I am gonna run with that. I will include “rock” towards the end. First up I am a huge Lindsey Stirling fan. She does epic original work. she does covers. She does an does a great cover of “Radioactive” with Pentatonix, but I think it may fall short of epic. What might better fit the original question is her Phantom of the Opera Medley: Phantom of the Opera - Lindsey Stirling Still avoiding rock, but keeping epic as a criteria, I agree with the oft mentioned Hurt as covered by Johnny Cash: Johnny Cash Hurt - Official Music Video I think we can even amp this one up some. Johnny’s cover of hurt was written shortly before his death, and it is clear in the video he was living that song. You just cannot fake that kind of authenticity. Just to amp up this theme maybe one notch, and edge closer to my self imposed “rock” criteria, I offer Disturbed’s cover of “The sound of silence: Disturbed - The Sound Of Silence [Official Music Video] Now you have had a chance to sample some of my musical tastes. This was all just a warmup for what I consider to be head and shoulders above all these. Consider one of the most arguably epic rock bands to date. They have so much respect for one another that the loss of one member causes the remaining members to disband, at possibly the height of their popularity. Their musical integrity is more important than a decade or two of additional lucrative touring and studio albums. Their lead singer has even been knighted by the Queen of England. The surviving members are being honored at the Kennedy center by a massive list of top-tier singers covering their most popular hits. Even the President of the United States is in attendance. The band is aprehensive, as they just KNOW that the final cover song of the night will be their signature song. The song that they HATE to hear played because it is just absolutely trashed by lesser musicians who really don’t understand the song, or have any idea how to play it. But that is not what happens. Not on this night. Enter Ann and Nancy Wilson of Heart. Enter the fallen bandmember’s son Jason Bonham. Watch this if you watch nothing else from this feed: Stairway to Heaven (Led Zeppelin Tribute) Heart's Ann and Nancy Wilson - 2012 Kennedy Center Honors You have a strong solid roll band covering possibly one of the most iconic songs of all time in front of the original singer, Robert Plant, who is on record despising covers of Stairway to Heaven. You have dozens of A-list musicians and celebrities in attendance. You have the President of the United States there. As they later said, “Its just Stairway to Heaven in front of Led Zeppelin and the President, no pressure!” And they played it so well they brought Robert Plant to tears with emotion. I cannot top this one.

John Lennon - Angel Baby  Originally a one-hit wonder by Rosie & The Originals, this song has been covered numerous times but John Lennon does it in a way that manages to capture the feelings of wailing for a lost youth. John’s solo works was good with the nostalgic bits. Charles Bradley - Changes  It’s difficult to find a soul and R’n’B cover of a rock song, let alone heavy metal, which makes this cover very refreshing. The way this guy does this song can move many-a-person to tears without question. Elliott Smith - Jealous Guy  To those familiar with this singer, it is no secret that he was heavily influenced by the Beatles so to hear him covering a John Lennon song is to be expected. His delicate tone adds an extra element of vulnerability that even the original couldn’t do. Uncle Tupelo - The Great Atomic Power  This song does an excellent job of giving this old Louvin Brothers classic a modern veneer. Opeth - Would?  Opeth may be progressive metal but their covers of classic rock songs are worth looking into so when I stumbled across their cover of this grunge song, I was blown away immediately. They manage to make it sound like the original without having to sacrifice their persona.

There are TONS of surprisingly great cover songs. Some of my fav’s include: Please Mr. Postman - Originally by The Marvelettes, covered by The Beatles.  I Call Your Name - Covered by The Mamas and Papas, originally released by Billy J Kramer and the Dakotas in 1963 and the Beatles in 1964.  Refugee - I don’t know how Tom Petty & The Heartbreakers felt about Melissa Etheridge’s cover of this great song but I thought it was a fantastic effort by Melissa and her band.  Sharp Dressed Man - I’ve never been much of a Nickelback fan but they KICKED ASS with this cover of the ZZ Top song during the 2007 Vh-1 Rock Honors.  Finally, the most recent one to surprise me a lot is actually from 2012 but I only came across it this past year, which is Stairway to Heaven as covered by Ann and Nancy Wilson of Heart, along with Jason Bonham, son of Led Zeppelin drummer John Bonham. It starts out with the Wilson sisters and as the song progresses, we have back-up singers, a string section, and the Joyce Garrett Youth Choir on stage to round out a totally moving rendition of this Zeppelin classic. Just incredible and even Robert Plant seemed impressed.

There are some cover songs that are such great renditions that reconvey all the feelings and emotions of the original songs taking them many steps forward. Some of such covers are well known covers, some others are so good most believe them to be the original and others stick loyal to the original composition with little to add to them. Here is my list of favorite renditions: Obscure covers that deserve more attention: MAN IN THE BOX, originally by Alice in Chains, covered by Phyllotaxis:  ENJOY THE SILENCE, originally by Depeche Mode, covered by Trevor Something. I wonder why this wasn’t picked for the Ghost in the Shell movie instead. Feels a lot more cyberpunk to me:  ROLLING IN THE DEEP, originally by Adele, covered by Greta Van Fleet. This is what a pop song sounds like in its rock n’ roll version:  NIGHT OF THE VAMPIRE, covered by Entombed, originally by Roky Erickson  DO THE EVOLUTION, originally by Pearl Jam, covered by death metal legends Criminal:  Little knew The Cure that with A FOREST they were opening the gates for a vast new genre in music, namely, Black Metal, that would come later in the early 90s with Burzum at least as we know it today. Here is a cover by Aeon Wind.  ANGIE, originally by The Rolling Stones, covered by Chilean rock Band La Ley. This cover is better than the original, and that’s a factual statements. I’m sorry. It just IS.  Then we have those covers everybody knows ARE covers and prefer them over the original… or at least, receive more attention than the song they cover: THE MAN WHO SOLD THE WORLD  VULGARIS MAGISTRALIS  I WILL ALWAYS LOVE YOU  GIRLS JUST WANNA HAVE FUN
